Edited by Anna McCormick to reflect the digitization and enhanced description of CCTV tapes done by Klavier J. Wang. Materials are mostly in English, with some materials in Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Spanish, and Arabic. Chinese language materials appear in both traditional and simplified scripts, and spoken Chinese recorded in AsianCinevision programs is mostly Cantonese, but some episodes include Mandarin Chinese, English, and various Cantonese-based dialects.
Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Asian CineVision Records
Asian CineVision (Organization)
Woo, John C.
TAM.416
314.25 Linear Feet in 313 record cartons, 1 legal manuscript box, 1 half manuscript box, 1 CD box, 1 poster tube, 1 oversize roll, and 1 oversize folder in a shared box.
6 websites in six archived websites.
circa 1975-2014 Asian CineVision (ACV), founded by grassroots media activists in New York's Chinatown in 1976, is a non-profit media arts organization that develops, promotes and preserves media made by or about peoples of Asian descent. ACV initiated the weekly, cable-access Chinese Cable Television (CCTV), 1977-1983, which covered a broad range of community-interest issues such as local politics, education, language, housing, labor and healthcare. Beginning in 1978, ACV sponsored the Asian American International Film Festival (AIIFF). ACV also publishes the Asian American media arts journal CineVue. This unprocessed collection consists of three series: I, Administrative Files of Asian CineVision; II, Research Files; III, Video Recordings in various formats from Chinese Cable Television (CCTV), and the Asian American International Film Festival (AAIFF). Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by John C. Woo on behalf of Asican CineVision, Inc. in 2007; additional materials were donated by the organization in 2011, 2013, 2017, and 2018. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 2008.007, 2008.008, NPA.2008.008, 2011.042, 2013.003, 2017.045, and 2018.135.
http://www.asiancinevision.org/ and http://aaiff.org/2014/ were initially selected by curators and captured through the use of The California Digital Library's Web Archiving Service in 2014 as part of the Arts and Cultural Left Web Archive. In 2015, these websites were migrated to Archive-It. Archive-It uses web crawling technology to capture websites at a scheduled time and displays only an archived copy, from the resulting WARC file, of the website. In 2018, http://aaiff.org/2018/ was added from a redirect of http://aaiff.org/. In 2019, http://aaiff.org/2015/, http://aaiff.org/2016/, and http://aaiff.org/2017/ were added. The accession number associated with these websites is 2019.125.
Arrangement
This unprocessed collection contains four series:
I. Administrative Files
II. Research Files
III. Video Recordings
IV. Addendum
V. Archived Websites
Historical Note
Asian CineVision (ACV) is a non-profit media arts organization that develops, promotes and preserves media made by or about peoples of Asian descent. Asian CineVision was founded by grassroots media activists in New York's Chinatown in 1976 to raise social and cultural awareness of the Asian American experience, both in the Asian American community and among the general public. Founders Tsui Hark, Christine Choy, Thomas Tam, Danny Yung and Peter Chow, and others also sought to raise awareness through media training in the local Chinese community. The organization sought to address problems of media access for Asian Americans and also to present and publicize the work of Asian American artists. The organization initiated the weekly, cable-access Chinese Cable Television (CCTV) in 1977, which covered a broad range of community-interest issues such as local politics, education, language, housing, labor and healthcare. Significantly, it was the first Chinese-language news program in the U.S. Production of CCTV ceased in 1983. Beginning in 1978, it has sponsored the Asian American (AIIFF) International Film Festival. In 1981, Asian CineVision assumed publication of Bridge magazine, a quarterly journal documenting the development of a pan-Asian American political and cultural identity previously published by the group Basement Workshop. Bridge ceased publication in 1986 and was replaced by the Asian American media arts journal CineVue. Through these and other programs, Asian CineVision supports Asian and Asian American mediamakers and presents their works to the Asian American community and wider audiences.
Custodial History
Asian CineVision, Inc. sent 238 boxes of records and graphics in 2007. Asian CineVision sent an additional 27 boxes of their records in 2011. In 2013, Asian CineVision sent an additional donation of 2 boxes containing posters, laptops and hard drives. In 2017 Asian CineVision sent three boxes of inventories and film festival programs.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Asian CineVision Records; TAM 416; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
To cite the archived website in this collection: Identification of item, date; Asian CineVision Records; TAM 416; Wayback URL; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Processing Information note
Processing decisions made prior to 2014 have not been recorded.
In 2014, the archived websites were added as Series V. The original finding aid was reformatted from a Word document to EAD in 2014.
In 2017, three boxes of inventories and festival programs were added to Series I: Administrative Files as boxes 311-313. Two floppy disks included in this donation were inventoried and forensically imgaged.
In 2018, two boxes of festival programs, publications, and office files were removed from hanging folders and rehoused in acid-free boxes. At the time of accessioning, these materials were added to the file list in Series I: Administrative Files. They have not been arranged by the archivist and are in the order in which they were received by the donor.
In 2019, the archived websites were added to the finding aid.
In 2020, 109 tapes from Series III, Sub-series A were digitized and described on the file level.
Scope and Contents
This unprocessed collection consists of four series: I, Administrative Files of Asian CineVision (boxes 1-78, less the eleven interfiled boxes of series two); II, Research Files, i.e., background files on Asian American cinema, including a large collection of film catalogues (includes some notes in Chinese, and catalogs and magazines Spanish, Arabic, Korean, and Japanese (boxes 21-28, 40, 53, 67); III, Video Recordings (in various formats), from (A) Chinese Cable Television (CCTV), boxes 79-159, and (B) Asian American International Film Festival (AAIFF), i.e., motion pictures, short films, documentaries, and other video materials gathered in preparation for the festival (boxes 160-273); Addendum, 2011-2013 (unprocessed; boxes 274-300), which contains unidentified materials, posters, hard drives, and laptops.
Materials added to this collecion in 2017 include Programs from Asian American International Film Festivals (AAIFF) and Asian American International Video Festivals (AAIVF), dated 1978-2003. They also include inventories of Asian CineVision video archives, and catalog indexes of AAIFF programs and the Chinese-American cultural magazine Bridge.
Materials added to this collection in 2018 include programs from Asian American International Film Festivals (AAIFF) and Asian American International Video Festivals (AAIVF), copies of the periodical Cinevue, and office files related to these materials, dated 1976-2003.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Portions of this unprocessed collection are either in fragile condition, poorly housed, or loose. Therefore, in certain instances preservation concerns may take precedence, and, at the discretion of Library staff, some materials may not be available for use.
Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
Conditions Governing Use
Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by Asian CineVision, Inc. were transferred to New York University in 2007 by John C. Woo. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu.
Take Down Policy
Archived websites are made accessible for purposes of education and research. NYU Libraries have given attribution to rights holders when possible; however, due to the nature of archival collections, we are not always able to identify this information.
If you hold the rights to materials in our archived websites that are unattributed, please let us know so that we may maintain accurate information about these materials.
If you are a rights holder and are concerned that you have found material on this website for which you have not granted permission (or is not covered by a copyright exception under US copyright laws), you may request the removal of the material from our site by submitting a notice, with the elements described below, to the repository email.
Please include the following in your notice: Identification of the material that you believe to be infringing and information sufficient to permit us to locate the material; your contact information, such as an address, telephone number, and email address; a statement that you are the owner, or authorized to act on behalf of the owner, of an exclusive right that is allegedly infringed and that you have a good-faith belief that use of the material in the manner complained of is not authorized by the copyright owner, its agent, or the law; a statement that the information in the notification is accurate and made under penalty of perjury; and your physical or electronic signature. Upon receiving a notice that includes the details listed above, we will remove the allegedly infringing material from public view while we assess the issues identified in your notice.

Scope and Contents
This episode includes three parts: street interviews, a 35-minute film, and an announcement section. In the street interviews, two hosts interview people about the newspapers they read, their views on international and domestic news, their impressions of last year, and their hopes for the coming year. The second part of the episode is a Curtis Choy film Dupont Guy: The Schiz of Grant Avenue (1976). The film narrates the struggles and experiences of being Chinese American.

Scope and Contents
This episode includes several parts: street interviews, coverage of a photo exhibition and a variety show, a 9-minute documentary, and an announcement section. In the street interviews, two hosts interview people about their views on subways in the city. The photo exhibition shows two Chinese photographers' works that depict life in Chinatown, including sweatshop laborers and street demonstrations for employment equality. The variety show is called China Nite and is organized by a local middle school. The documentary film contains intertitles that read Brute Force Cybernetics presents Second Campaign and Berkeley May 1969.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Format: 3/4" Umatic, Duration: 53 minutesVideo 224: CCTVCuid9270January 20, 198091Cuid9270
Scope and Contents
This episode includes three parts: a news report on a local demonstration, a 19-minute documentary, and an announcement section. The first part covers housing issues faced by a group of Chinatown residents, who organized demonstrations against the landlord Thomas Sung. Interviews with the disaffected tenants and Thomas Sung (孫啟誠) are included. The second part shows a documentary film Jenny (1977), which is produced by Japanese American Ginny Hashii. The documentary narrates the experiences of being Japanese American in the United States.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Format: 3/4" Umatic, Duration 55 minutes.Video 225: CCTVCuid9271January 27, 198091Cuid9271
Scope and Contents
This episode includes three parts: street interviews, a Hong Kong film, and an announcement section. In the street interviews, two hosts interview people about heat provision in their apartments. Interviewees complain about having difficulties getting heat in the winter, and they suggest it is landlords' responsibility to take care of this matter. The second part of the episode is an Allen Fong (方育平) film The Wild Child (野孩子) (1977). The film depicts the ups and downs of a young boy's life who lives with his grandmother in a rural village.

Format: Umatic, Duration: 57 minutesVideo 226: CCTVCuid9272February 3, 198091Cuid9272
Scope and Contents
This episode includes several parts: news reports on Chinese athletes visiting the United States and Chinese students having dinner gathering, a 26-minute Hong Kong film, coverage of a labor demonstration, and an announcement section. The first part reports the US-China Peoples Friendship Association receiving People's Republic of China athletes who for the first time attend the Winter Olympics. Interviews with athletes and officials from China are included. The second part covers a dinner gathering organized by the National Association of Chinese-Americans. The third part is an Allen Fong (方育平) film Song of Yuen Chau Chai (元洲仔之歌) (1977), which depicts the lives of fishermen in Hong Kong. The fourth section covers a labor demonstration against a Chinese restaurant called House of Chan. Laborers demand recognition of their union by the employer.

Scope and Contents
This episode includes two parts: a travel program and coverage of a ceremony in New York City. The first part is a program called Travelogue (遊蹤處處), the host introduces a skate rink in Coney Island in New York City, presumably the Abe Stark. Interviews with some skaters are included. The second part covers a ceremony in which President of the City Council Carol Bellamy presents awards to community art groups, including CCTV. The ceremony is held at the Marble Collegiate Church, 1 West 29th Street.

Scope and Contents
This episode features activities of Chinese people in New York City celebrating the lunar new year. Activities shown in the episode include singing and dancing shows, martial arts (Kung Fu), and a lion dance performance. The episode also includes interviews with the performers. In the last part, the host of the episode tells traditional stories relevant to the Chinese lunar new year (Year of the Monkey).

Scope and Contents
This episode includes three parts: a segment on First Lady Rosalynn Carter's visit to Chinatown, another on a Yale University professor visiting Chinatown with students, and a feature on a Chinese culinary school. In the first part, a banquet is held in a Chinese restaurant to receive Mrs. Carter's visit; Mrs. Carter and others give speeches. The second part includes interviews with the Yale professor - who is Chinese - and the students. The third part features a special program called At Your Service (爲你服務), which introduces culinary and English lessons offered by the China Institute. Interviews with the institute organizer and culinary lesson participants are included.

Scope and Contents
This episode includes four parts: street interviews, a lunar new year festival show, a banquet dinner, and an interview with a lawyer. In the first part, the hosts ask people what their views are on the robbery of Chinatown Lincoln Savings Bank. The second part presents a lunar new year performance show organized by the Better Chinatown Project (美化華埠). The third part features a banquet organized by the Chinese American Chamber of Commerce to welcome Winter Olympic athletes from the People's Republic of China. Interviews with athletes are included. The last part is an interview with Benjamin Gim, a representative of the Chinese Lawyers Association.

Format: 3/4" Umatic, Duration: 53 minutesVideo 231: CCTVCuid9277March 9, 198092Cuid9277
Scope and Contents
This episode includes three parts: a segment on First Lady Rosalynn Carter's visit to Chinatown, street interviews, and a 29-minute documentary. In the first part, a banquet is held at the Silver Palace restaurant to receive Mrs. Carter's visit. Mrs. Carter and other Chinese representatives give speeches. This is the first time the First Lady of the United States visits Chinatown for presidential election fundraising. In the second part, two hosts comment on the disadvantages of smoking and interview people about their views on smoking. The third part is a PBS documentary Emi (1979). The other name of the documentary is Pearls. It is directed by Michael Uno and Frank Nesbitt, about Japanese-American Emiko Tonooka's experience in a California internment camp during World War Two.

Scope and Contents
This episode includes three parts: interviews with children, a segment on a fundraising banquet, and a 35-minute film. In the first part, two hosts interview children and teenagers about their views on watching television. The second part is about a banquet held in Chinatown to support Ted Kennedy running for the presidential election. Present at the banquet include congressman John Murphy, and New York state Kennedy for president campaign manager Richard Donahue. The third part is a Curtis Choy film Dupont Guy: The Schiz of Grant Avenue (1976). The film narrates the struggles and experiences of being Chinese American.

Scope and Contents
This episode includes five parts: a segment on the visit of a Shanghai acrobatic theater, an interview with Chinese playwright Cao Yu (曹禺), coverage of an academic conference, and a special program on the 1980 census. The first part is about the Shanghai acrobatic troupe's US-tour show. The second part covers Chinese playwright Cao Yu's visit to Columbia University. An interview with Cao Yu is also included. The third part is about a conference organized by Asian Women United, a New York-based women's organization. The fourth part is a performance by Chinese singer Zi Wei (紫薇), who is also interviewed. Lastly, the episode includes advertisements to promote the 1980 census, with a special program on the history and operation of census (including interviews with census workers).

The third part includes street interviews with Chinatown residents about their views on the 1980 census.

Scope and Contents
This episode has four parts: a report on an award presentation banquet in Chinatown, an interview with a Chinese playwright, street interviews, and a special program. In the first part, a banquet is held at the Silver Palace restaurant where the Council of Asian-American Women presents an award to Congresswoman Elizabeth Holtzman. Holtzman is interviewed about her views on immigration and refugee issues. The second part is an interview with Chinese playwright Cao Yu (曹禺). There are scenes from stage performances of Cao Yu's works - the English version of Sunrise (日出) and Peking Man (北京人). In the third part, a host interviews Chinatown residents about their views on the 1980 New York City transit strike. The last section is a special program about the 1980 census. The host interviews three census program staff members, asking them to provide details on the purpose and operation of the census.

Scope and Contents
This episode has four parts: a coverage of an award presentation banquet in Chinatown, excerpts of a cultural festival, a feature report about a vocational training school, and interviews with teenagers. In the first part, a banquet is held at the Silver Palace restaurant where the Council of Asian-American Women presents an award to Congresswoman Elizabeth Holtzman. Holtzman is interviewed about her views on immigration and refugee issues. The second part shows excerpts of a music cultural festival held at Shuang Wen School located in Manhattan's Chinatown. The third part is a feature program called At Your Service (爲你服務), which covers a hotel management vocational training school. The school is operated by Jack Han. This episode includes four sections: street interviews, excerpts of a cultural performance, a travel program, and interviews with martial art performers. The first part includes street interviews with Chinatown residents. Interviewees express views on the changes of Chinatown, such as the expansion of the Chinese population, and the increasing number of stores and garment manufacture factories. The second part shows excerpts of Chinese Cultural Center's performance at Murry Bergtraum High School. The third part is a program called Travelogue (遊蹤處處). In this episode, Sheepshead Bay in New York City, New York state is introduced. The fourth section introduces a martial art school in Chinatown. In the second part, hosts interview Chinatown residents about their views on the Silver Palace Restaurant labor strike. The third part features a special program called Asian American Experience, in which Asian-American young people are preparing for the American Heritage Week exhibition. The local news also covers a forum organized by the Asian Americans for Equality on the issue of rental increase in Chinatown. The second part features traditional Chinese cultural activities.

Scope and Contents
This video includes an interview with Chinese American artists who participate in an exhibition at Washington Square Park, New York City, a chewing gum advertisement produced by the second session of CCTV Production and Performance workshop, a sit-com featuring miscommunication between Mandarin and Cantonese speaking families, and interviews with Confucius Plaza residents. Also included is an interview with Mr. Lo, the vice-chairman of Confucius Plaza co-op project. He introduces the history of building the Confucius Plaza which is under the Mitchell-Lama Housing Program. The episode also shows a situation drama which features dilemmas in a Chinese American family. The end of the episode includes clips of lectures during the second CCTV Production and Performance workshop.

Scope and Content Note
Asian CineVision (ACV) is a non-profit media arts organization that develops, promotes and preserves media made by or about peoples of Asian descent. Asian CineVision was founded by grassroots media activists in New York's Chinatown in 1976 to raise social and cultural awareness of the Asian American experience, both in the Asian American community and among the general public. CineVue Online is ACV's media arts journal established in 1986. The websites contains their media arts journal, information on their Asian American International Film Festival, specifically the 2014-2018 editions of the festival, news listings, event listings, trailers and descriptions of films in the festival, and press releases.
Accruals
New site crawls are accrued semiannually.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.
Appraisal
Crawl was limited to domains and subdomains of aaiff.org and asiancinevision.org in order to remain within the collection scope and data constraints.
